text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 4.25.14, Estate and Gift Tax, Miscellaneous Procedures.
The deﬁnition to Estate and Gift Notebook in IRM 4.25.14.1.4 (1) was revised to remove the comparison to RGS.
The acronym table located in 4.25.14.1.4, Terms/Deﬁnitions/Acronyms, paragraph (2) was revised to remove to acronyms that are no longer being used in IRM 4.25.14.
IRM 4.25.2.2 paragraph (3) was revised to add a citation to 26 CFR 1.6081-5(a).

IRM 4.25.14.2.3 paragraphs (2) through (4), the last sentence in paragraph (5), paragraph (6) and paragraph (9) were removed. This content is in IRM 4.25.2.8.2.4, Extension of Time to File and IRC 6161 Extension of Time to Pay.
IRM 4.25.14.3.2, Liens Arising Under IRC 6324A, is being obsoleted. Guidance and procedures related to collection activity for liens arising under IRC 6234A is in IRM 5.5.1, and IRMs 5.5.5 through

IRM 4.25.14.3.3, Liens Arising Under IRC 6324B, is being obsoleted. Guidance and procedures related to collection activity for liens arising under IRC 6234A is in IRM 5.5.1, and IRMs 5.5.5 through IRM 5.5.9.

IRM 4.25.14.4, Issuing Transfer Certiﬁcates in Estate Tax Cases, is being obsoleted. E&G Campus procedures related to the issuance of Transfer Certiﬁcates are located in IRM 4.25.2.5.11, Transfer Certiﬁcate Requests.
4.25.14.6, Revenue agent Referrals to Estate and Gift Tax, is being obsoleted. Revenue agent referral procedures are located in IRM 4.25.3.9, Consultations and Referrals from Other Business Units.
The language in IRM 4.25.14.8.1 paragraph (2) was moved to IRM 4.25.14.8, Reopening Procedures for Estate Tax Returns, paragraph (3).
The phrase “attempting to reopen” was changed to “reopening” in IRM 4.25.14.8.2 paragraph (1).
IRM 42.5.14.11.1, Activity Codes used in Estate and Gift Tax Examinations, is being obsoleted. This content is available in Document 6209 and Document 6036.
IRM 4.25.14.11.2, Aging Reason Codes for Estate and Gift Tax Examinations, is being obsoleted. This content is available in IRM 4.4.1-1, AIMS Procedures, Reference Guide.
IRM 4.25.14.11.3, MFT Codes used for Estate and Gift Tax Examinations, is being obsoleted. This content is available in Document 6209.

IRM 4.25.14.11.5, Source Codes Used in Estate and Gift Tax Examinations, is being obsoleted. This content is available in Document 6209 and in IRM 4.4.34.4.16, AIMS Procedures and Processing Instructions, Updating/Correcting AIMS Database, Source Code.
IRM 4.25.14.11.6, Status Codes Used in Estate and Gift Tax Examinations, is being obsoleted. This content is available in Document 6209.
IRM 4.25.14.11.7, Tracking Codes used in Estate and Gift Tax Examinations, is being obsoleted. This content is available in Document 6209 and also available on the Estate and Gift SharePoint.
Editorial changes have been made throughout this IRM. Website addresses, legal references, and IRM references were reviewed and updated as necessary.
The July 30, 2019 publication of IRM 4.25.14 is superseded.
AUDIENCE
This section contains instructions and guidelines for Small Business/Self Employed Estate and Gift Tax Specialty Programs employees.
Table of Contents
and (

) General Overview - This IRM provides information about miscellaneous and gift tax examiner responsibilities, estate and gift tax IRM sections, and forms used in the examination of estate, gift and generation skipping transfer tax returns and claims. (

) Purpose - This IRM explains Estate and Gift examiner responsibilities so managers, senior-level officials and estate, gift and generation skipping tax return examiners will be better equipped to prepare and submit accurate reports. (
) Audience - This IRM is for Estate and Gift Specialty Tax managers, examiners and personnel at the Campus who process estate, gift and generation skipping transfer tax returns, refunds and claims. (

) Policy Owner - Director, Examination - Specialty Policy is responsible for administration, procedures and updates related to the technical guidance and information processing steps and methods speciﬁc to Estate and Gift Tax examiner responsibilities, IRM subsections, and forms created for the examina- tion of returns and claims. (
) Program Owner - Director, Examination - Specialty Examination owns Estate and Gift Tax Examination. (

) Primary Stakeholders - Advisory Collections, Appeals, Counsel, Estate and Gift Tax Workload Selection and Delivery, Specialty Examination, and SB/SE Examination Quality & Technical Support are the primary stakeholders for IRM. (

) This IRM subsection provides miscellaneous procedures associated with the examination of estate, generation skipping transfer tax and gift tax returns. This IRM contains guidance related to extensions, liens and IDRS codes unique to estate and gift tax examinations, and links to various Servicewide resources. (

) Estate and gift tax examiners and managers assigned to examine and oversee the examination of estate and gift tax returns and issues are responsible for complying with servicewide policies and authorities set forth in IRM
, Servicewide Policies and Authorities, Policy Statements for the Examining Process. (
) Examination of estate and gift tax returns should be conducted in a manner that will promote public conﬁdence as stated in the Mission of the Service. IRM
, and Policy Statement
) Policy Statement
established a general guideline that examination and processing of returns should be completed within
months of the ﬁling date. See IRM
, Policy Statement

) Estate and gift examiners and managers assigned to examine and oversee examination of international estate and gift tax returns and issues are respon- sible for complying with all applicable servicewide examination delegation orders and SB/SE delegation orders. requires the Service to include an explanation of the examination and collection process, as well as informa- tion about assistance from the Taxpayer Advocate with any ﬁrst report/notice proposed deﬁciency. Pub
, The Examination Process, must be used for this purpose. (
) Statement of Procedural Rules
requires that examiners must forward any correspondence (or copy), discussions, reports and/or other material to taxpayer at the same time it is sent to the representative. (

) The National Quality Review System (NQRS) is a web-based review system used by Estate and Gift Tax Policy, Estate and Gift Tax Examination Manage- ment and Estate and Gift Tax Quality Measures and Analysis (QMA) to generate and review reports analyzing national quality performance based upon standardized quality attributes set forth in Document

, Estate and Gift Tax Examination Embedded Quality Job Aid. NQRS report data is compiled by QMA on a quarterly basis, but ad hoc reports may be obtained monthly. The use of NQRS is explained in additional detail in IRM
, Manager Embedded Quality Review and Specialty Exam National Embedded Quality Review Programs. (

) Operational Reviews and related NQRS reports are conducted by Territory Managers and the Chief, Estate and Gift to measure national adherence to quality standards and managerial performance and/or oversight. (

) Customer (i.e. taxpayer) satisfaction reports are generated by SB/SE Operation Support Research on a quarterly basis. These reports provide masked taxpayer narratives that are responsive to a pre-deﬁned set of survey questions. The quarterly survey reports are used to identify areas for examina- tion quality improvement. (
) Frequent front-line manager reviews are conducted under the Examination Quality Review System (EQRS), with the frequency based on annual personnel requirements. (

) This section provides an introduction to extensions of time to ﬁle and to pay which are available to the taxpayer in estate and gift tax matters. (
) A request for an extension of time to ﬁle must be made by the due date of return. A request for an extension that is not timely may be granted upon a showing of good and sufficient cause. See IRM
, Estate and Gift Tax, Campus Estate and Gift, Extension Procedures. Time to Returns (
) IRC
provides for the extension of time to ﬁle estate and gift tax returns. Form
, United States Estate (and Generation-Skipping Transfer) Tax Return, is generally due within nine months after the date of death. An estate may ﬁle Form
, Application for Extension of Time to File a Return Pay U.S. Estate (and Generation-Skipping Transfer) Taxes, to apply for an extension of time to ﬁle. See IRM
, Form
, Application for Extension of Time to File a Return and/or Pay U.S. Estate (and Generation- Skipping Transfer) Taxes. (
) An estate may apply for an automatic six month extension of time to ﬁle a Form
, Form
-A, Form
-D, Form
-NA or Form
-QDT. Unless the executor is out of the country, the maximum extension of time to ﬁle is months from the due date of the applicable return. (
) A request for an extension of time to ﬁle must be made by the due date of return. (
) No acknowledgement of the extension approval is sent to the taxpayer. (
) An extension of time to ﬁle does not extend the time to pay. (
) If the extension is approved , Transaction Code (TC)
will be present transcripts followed by the approved extension date. (
) If the extension is denied , Transaction Code (TC)
will be present on scripts followed by “Denied”. Time to Returns - (
) A Form
, United States Gift (and Generation-Skipping Transfer) Tax is generally due on April
following the close of the calendar year in which the gift was made. If the donor dies in the calendar year in which the donor made a gift, the Form
is due on or before the due date of the estate return (including extensions), or on April
of the year following the calendar year of the gift, whichever date is earlier. (
) Except as provided in IRC
with respect to certain U.S. citizens and residents living outside the United States, an extension of time to ﬁle a gift return may not exceed six months from the due date of the return. See
CFR
) A request for an extension of time to ﬁle must be made by the original due date of the return, without extensions other than the automatic extension U.S. citizens and residents abroad provided in
CFR

A donor may apply for an extension of time to pay gift tax or as to a deﬁciency of gift tax. See Form 1127, Application for Extension of Time for Payment of Tax Due to Undue Hardship, and IRM 5.5.5.9, Extension Requests to Pay Gift Tax. All extension requests are processed at the Estate and Gift Operation at the E&G Campus. See IRM 4.25.2.8.2.4, Extension of Time to File and IRC 6161 Extension of Time to Pay.
) Estate Tax Extension of to Pay - IRC
) IRC

(a) permits an extension for paying estate tax on the value of a sionary or remainder interest in the property included in the gross estate. time for payment will be postponed for six months after the termination of preceding interest in the property. See IRM
, Estate Tax Extension of Time to Pay Under IRC
, for E&G Campus processing procedures. (
) IRC
(b) permits the extension of time for paying the estate tax that was granted under IRC
(a) if the estate can show reasonable cause for the additional extension. The extension may be for up to an additional three from the expiration date of the postponement provided for in IRC
(a). Neither tax nor accrued interest is due and payable until six months after precedent interest terminates. (

) An estate that elected to postpone that part of the estate tax attributable to reversionary or remainder interest may prepay a portion of the outstanding liability without payment of accrued interest or acceleration of the remaining tax. See Rev. Rul.

) Processing of Requests Discharge of Property Subject to the Estate Tax Lien (

) This section provides guidance with respect to the various types of estate gift tax liens as to which discharge may be applied for by taxpayers, their resentatives, or other interested parties. Under IRC

, liens arise by operation of law as to unpaid estate or gift tax. Responsibility for consideration of the release of property from these unrecorded liens will fall to the Advisory Estate Tax Lien Group. See IRM
, Advisory Responsibilities for Process- ing Estate Tax Liens. (
) Discharge of property may be requested from the special recorded liens that are unique to the estate tax area: • The lien under IRC
A that is provided to secure the interest of government as to assessed tax for which the payment is deferred to an election under IRC
• The lien under IRC
B that is provided to secure the interest of government as to potential recapture tax imposed under IRC
A(c) and IRC

) Estate and Gift Examination will provide written communication of their mendations on issues such as ﬁling requirements; potential audit issues, Revenue Agent Report (RAR), or proper calculations of recapture tax returns within
business days. (
) See the following Collection IRMs for guidance regarding collection in estate, gift and generation-skipping transfer tax cases: • IRM
, Decedent and Estate Tax Accounts • IRM
, Processing Estate and Gift Tax Extensions
Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
J (
• IRM
, Collection on Accounts with Special Estate Tax Elections • IRM
, Collecting Estate and Gift Tax Accounts • IRM
, Advisory Responsibilities for Processing Estate Tax Liens • IRM
, Administrative and Judicial Actions for Estate Taxes Arising Under IRC (
) IRC

(a) imposes, by operation of law, a lien for the estate tax upon the gross estate of a decedent for a period of ten years from the date of death (excepting such part of the gross estate as is used for the payment of charges against the estate and expenses of administration, allowed by any court jurisdiction thereof). This lien is a “silent” lien and is distinguished from many other types of tax liens in that no recordation is required. (
) IRC

(b) imposes, by operation of law, a lien upon all gifts made during period for which a gift tax return is ﬁled and existing for a term of ten years from the date the gifts are made. Further, if the gift tax is not paid when due, the donee of any gift is personally liable for the gift tax due to the extent of value of the gift. This lien, like the IRC
(a) lien, is also an unrecorded (
) Certain exceptions exist, and application may be made to IRS by the taxpayer for the discharge of speciﬁc items of property from the liens imposed under IRC
This is most commonly encountered with respect to the statutory lien imposed with respect to estate tax under IRC
(a). If application is made on behalf of an estate, it must be ﬁled by the personal representative the estate, or a party properly authorized for representation pursuant to a power of attorney. (
) Form
, Application for Certiﬁcate Discharging Property Subject to Estate Tax Lien, is submitted to request a discharge under IRC
(c). Form
, United States Certiﬁcate Discharging Property Subject to Estate Tax Lien, used to approve the discharge of speciﬁcally described property under IRC
(c). Required Estate and Gift and Advisory (

) In any case where the Advisory Estate Tax Lien Group is called upon to process a request for a release of any of the estate tax liens speciﬁed in section, or a discharge of speciﬁc property subject thereto or for the subordina- tion of any of these liens, and the amount of the government’s lien interest cannot be determined, Advisory will consult with Estate and Gift for assistance in determining the amount of this interest. (

) The Advisory Estate Tax Lien Group may submit requests for assistance to Estate and Gift using the SRS referral system. Estate and Gift will provide written response within ten business days of receipt of the SRS referral. Processing and (
) All lien and discharge request ﬁles processed by Advisory will be maintained by Advisory. (
) Copies of lien discharge requests processed by Estate and Gift ﬁeld groups, prior to ﬁscal year
, will be associated with the original return ﬁles. (
) Form

, United States Certiﬁcate Discharging property Subject to Estate Lien, and relate material which may have been inadvertently retained by the Estate and Gift ﬁeld groups, are subject to the same records destruction as Advisory. Refer to Document

Certain exceptions exist, and application may be made to IRS by the taxpayer for the discharge of speciﬁc items of property from the liens imposed under IRC 6324. This is most commonly encountered with respect to the statutory lien imposed with respect to estate tax under IRC 6324(a). If application is made on behalf of an estate, it must be ﬁled by the personal representative of the estate, or a party properly authorized for representation pursuant to a valid power of attorney.
Copies of lien discharge requests processed by Estate and Gift ﬁeld groups, prior to ﬁscal year 2017, will be associated with the original return ﬁles.

(NARA) approved records disposition to prevent unauthorized/unlawful destruc- tion of records. Also refer to IRM 1.15, Records and Information Management series for records creation, maintenance, retention and disposition guidance. Before any lien discharge is destroyed, current IDRS transcripts should be obtained to ensure that there is no balance owed on the account. Where such material remains in possession of a ﬁeld Estate and Gift group, a best practice is to destroy only after the assessment SOL has expired and with assurance that there is no outstanding balance on the tax module.
is to destroy only after the assessment SOL has expired and with assurance that there is no outstanding balance on the tax module. (
) An executor or other ﬁduciary may ﬁle a Form
, Request for Discharge from Personal Liability Under Internal Revenue Code Section
or

, with respect to an estate or gift tax return. If the Service makes no notiﬁcation of determination of estate tax within nine months of the received dated of the prompt assessment request, the executor is automatically discharged from personal liability (applying only to him in his personal capacity and his personal assets). However, if a ﬁduciary other than an executor ﬁles a Form
, the IRS has six months to notify the ﬁduciary. See IRC
and IRC

a. The executor remains liable for assets of the estate that are in his pos- session or control. Also, the discharge does not release the estate assets from the lien for estate tax, if a deﬁciency is determined to be due. b. If the executor has applied for an extension of time in paying tax under IRC
, IRC
, or IRC

, a discharge from personal liability may still be requested. c. The Service has nine months to notify the executor of the amount of bond required to be posted. If no notice is given, the executor is dis- charged from personal liability. (

applications for discharge of personal liability ﬁled pursuant to IRC
and IRC
) IRM

, Information Referrals, details the process for employees to refer leads and information from newspapers, informants, practitioners or other sources to the Campus to determine if there is audit potential. (

) Any credible leads or information with audit potential relating to underreporting or nonﬁling of estate and gift taxes should be referred to the Campus. Sources of leads and information can include informants (e.g., co-executors, beneﬁcia- ries, family members, employees and neighbors) and articles and reports from newspapers, magazines, internet or other mass media. Procedures Returns (
) This section provides examination reopening procedures for estate tax returns where a Letter
, Estate Tax Closing Letter, was issued. (

) The estate and gift tax reopening case procedures vary depending on the manner in which the case was originally closed. Before an examiner requests that a case be reopened, the examiner should determine whether the case was accepted as ﬁled, surveyed, or examined. (
) Reopening criteria include substantial error, fraud, malfeasance, and serious administrative omission. Examples of reopening criteria, also called case criteria, can be found at IRM
, Case Return Criteria. Surveyed” as Filed” (
) A return in which Letter

, Estate Tax Closing Letter was issued after being “Accepted as Filed” or “Surveyed” can be opened for examination with the group manager’s approval. When making an examination determination regarding this type of return, the reopening criteria should be considered. taxpayer should be advised of the reasons for the examination. Examined (
) The following procedures should be followed when reopening an examined case: a. Requests must include a completed Form

, Reopening Memoran- dum, including a narrative. b. Requests must be submitted via secure e-mail to the group manager review. All attachments and additional information will be included in same secure e-mail. Upon concurrence with the examiner’s determina- tion the group manager will forward the e-mail to the Territory Manager for signature approval. c. The Territory Manager will forward the completed electronic form to Estate and Gift, for signature. d. The completed signed form will be returned to the Territory Manager. Activity (
) General guidance on the use of Suspicious Activity Reports (SAR) in Title civil income tax cases is provided in IRM
, Bank Secrecy Act, Disclo- sure. See also IRM
) Employees in the estate and gift program authorized to electronically access SAR information are designated Gatekeepers. The designated Fi
EN Gate- keeper is in E&G Workload Selection and Delivery. (

) Employees in the estate and gift program authorized to receive and use SAR information include: a. Estate Tax Attorneys b. Estate Tax Examiners c. Estate and Gift Group Managers d. Paralegals e. Legal Assistants f. Policy Attorney-Advisors and Analysts g. WSD Attorney-Advisors and Analysts Procedures
page (
) Internal Revenue Manual
This section provides examination reopening procedures for estate tax returns where a Letter 627, Estate Tax Closing Letter, was issued.
a. Requests must include a completed Form

, Reopening Memoran- dum, including a narrative. b. Requests must be submitted via secure e-mail to the group manager for review. All attachments and additional information will be included in the same secure e-mail. Upon concurrence with the examiner’s determina- tion the group manager will forward the e-mail to the Territory Manager for signature approval. c. The Territory Manager will forward the completed electronic form to Chief, Estate and Gift, for signature. d. The completed signed form will be returned to the Territory Manager.
